title: Integrating Extra Modality Helps Segmentor Find Camouflaged Objects Well
author: Chengyu Fang (SIGS, Tsinghua University), Chunming He (BME, Duke University), Longxiang Tang (SIGS, Tsinghua University), Yuelin Zhang (MAE, The Chinese University of Hong Kong), Chenyang Zhu (SIGS, Tsinghua University), Yuqi Shen (SIGS, Tsinghua University), Chubin Chen (SIGS, Tsinghua University), Xiu Li (SIGS, Tsinghua University)
relevance_why: The paper explores multi-modal data integration for enhanced segmentation performance in camouflaged object detection, which can inform techniques in audio event recognition and signal classification tasks.
background: Camouflaged object segmentation (COS) involves identifying difficult-to-detect targets within scenes where these objects blend in with their backgrounds.
contribution: This paper introduces UniCOS, a framework that employs a multimodal segmentor and a cross-modal knowledge learning module to enhance the detection of camouflaged objects, achieving superior segmentation accuracy.
technical_comparison: Previous methods have largely relied on single-modal data for segmentation, which limits performance in complex scenarios. This work improves by integrating multimodal features, allowing for a more contextual understanding that significantly enhances detection capabilities.
key_innovation: The unique incorporation of a cross-modal knowledge learning plugin enables the effective use of unrelated multimodal data to improve segmentation performance without direct pairings of data.
real_world_impact: This research has the potential to enhance object detection systems in various fields such as surveillance, robotics, and environmental monitoring where identifying concealed objects is critical.
limitations: The paper does not mention specific limitations or challenges encountered during the study.

new_terms.camouflaged object segmentation (COS): **Camouflaged object segmentation (COS)** refers to the process of detecting and segmenting objects that are visually indistinguishable from their background.
new_terms.cross-modal knowledge learning: **Cross-modal knowledge learning** involves transferring information between different types of data (e.g., RGB and infrared images) to improve model performance.
new_terms.uni-modal: **Uni-modal** refers to data or methodologies that operate using a single type of input, such as just RGB images without additional data modalities.

open_sourcing: Our code will be made publicly available on GitHub.
